questions.question: A monorail traveling at an initial speed of $32\text{ m/s}$ begins to slow down uniformly at a rate of $1.8\text{ m/s}^2$ as it approaches a platform. Calculate the speed of the monorail after it has traveled $120\text{ m}$ from the point where it started braking.
An RC car starts from rest and covers a distance of $45\text{ m}$ in $4.2\text{ s}$ with uniform acceleration. Determine the final velocity of the car at the end of this distance.
questions.explanation: Using $s = \frac{u+v}{2} \times t$: $45 = \frac{0+v}{2} \times 4.2 \rightarrow 45 = 2.1v \rightarrow v = 45/2.1 \approx 21.43 \approx 21\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A ball is thrown vertically upward and reaches a maximum height of $18\text{ m}$ above its release point. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the total time the ball remains in the air before returning to the release point.
questions.explanation: First find initial velocity: $v^2 = u^2 - 2gh \rightarrow 0 = u^2 - 2(9.8)(18) \rightarrow u = \sqrt{352.8} = 18.78\text{ m/s}$. Time to peak: $t_{up} = u/g = 18.78/9.8 = 1.92\text{ s}$. Total time = $2 \times 1.92 \approx 3.84 \approx 3.8\text{ s}$.

questions.question: A lead weight is dropped from rest from a bridge. If it takes $3.6\text{ s}$ to reach the water below, calculate the height of the bridge above the surface. Neglect air resistance.
questions.explanation: Using $h = \frac{1}{2}gt^2 = 4.9 \times (3.6)^2 = 4.9 \times 12.96 = 63.504 \approx 64\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A tennis ball is served horizontally from a height of $2.4\text{ m}$ at a speed of $28\text{ m/s}$. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the horizontal distance it travels before hitting the court.
questions.explanation: Time of fall: $t = \sqrt{2h/g} = \sqrt{4.8/9.8} = \sqrt{0.4898} = 0.70\text{ s}$. Horizontal distance: $x = vt = 28 \times 0.70 = 19.6 \approx 20\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A soccer ball is kicked at an angle of $35^{\circ}$ above the horizontal with an initial speed of $22\text{ m/s}$. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the maximum vertical height reached by the ball.
questions.explanation: Vertical component: $u_y = 22\sin(35^{\circ}) = 22 \times 0.5736 = 12.62\text{ m/s}$. Maximum height: $h_{max} = \frac{u_y^2}{2g} = \frac{(12.62)^2}{19.6} = \frac{159.3}{19.6} \approx 8.13 \approx 8.1\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A projectile is launched from ground level. Its initial vertical velocity component is $15\text{ m/s}$ and its horizontal component is $20\text{ m/s}$. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the total time of flight.
questions.explanation: Time of flight depends only on the vertical motion: $t = \frac{2u_y}{g} = \frac{2 \times 15}{9.8} = \frac{30}{9.8} \approx 3.06 \approx 3.1\text{ s}$.

questions.question: A boat heads due North across a river at a speed of $4.2\text{ m/s}$ relative to the water. The river current flows due East at $1.8\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the boat's resultant speed relative to a stationary observer on the bank.
questions.explanation: The two velocity components are perpendicular, so the resultant speed is $v = \sqrt{(4.2)^2 + (1.8)^2} = \sqrt{17.64 + 3.24} = \sqrt{20.88} \approx 4.57 \approx 4.6\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: Car A is traveling at $95\text{ km/h}$ due North and Car B is traveling at $110\text{ km/h}$ due South. Calculate the velocity of Car B relative to Car A.
questions.explanation: Taking North as positive, $v_A = +95\text{ km/h}$, $v_B = -110\text{ km/h}$. Relative velocity: $\vec{v}_{B/A} = \vec{v}_B - \vec{v}_A = (-110) - (95) = -205\text{ km/h [N]} = 205\text{ km/h [S]}$.

questions.question: A crate of mass $45\text{ kg}$ is pushed across a horizontal floor with a horizontal force of $160\text{ N}$. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between the crate and the floor is $0.28$, calculate the acceleration of the crate.
questions.explanation: Friction force: $f_k = \mu_k mg = 0.28 \times 45 \times 9.8 = 0.28 \times 441 = 123.48\text{ N}$. Net force: $F_{net} = 160 - 123.48 = 36.52\text{ N}$. Acceleration: $a = F_{net}/m = 36.52/45 \approx 0.812 \approx 0.81\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A car of mass $1400\text{ kg}$ is traveling at $22\text{ m/s}$. If a constant braking force of $6500\text{ N}$ is applied, calculate the distance required to bring the car to a complete stop.

A $2.5\text{ kg}$ block is pulled across a horizontal floor at constant velocity by a horizontal force of $8.0\text{ N}$. Calculate the coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the floor.
questions.explanation: At constant velocity, the applied force equals the friction force: $F_{app} = f_k = \mu_k mg$. Thus $\mu_k = \frac{F_{app}}{mg} = \frac{8.0}{2.5 \times 9.8} = \frac{8.0}{24.5} \approx 0.327 \approx 0.33$.

questions.question: A $12\text{ kg}$ block is placed on a frictionless ramp inclined at $25^{\circ}$ to the horizontal. Calculate the magnitude of the force acting parallel to the ramp.
questions.explanation: The parallel component of weight is $F_\parallel = mg\sin\theta = 12 \times 9.8 \times \sin(25^{\circ}) = 117.6 \times 0.4226 \approx 49.7 \approx 50\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A $5.5\text{ kg}$ mass slides down an incline of $32^{\circ}$. If the kinetic friction force acting on it is $14\text{ N}$, calculate the acceleration of the mass down the ramp.
questions.explanation: Component of weight down the ramp: $mg\sin\theta = 5.5 \times 9.8 \times \sin(32^{\circ}) = 53.9 \times 0.5299 = 28.56\text{ N}$. Net force: $F_{net} = 28.56 - 14 = 14.56\text{ N}$. Acceleration: $a = F_{net}/m = 14.56/5.5 \approx 2.647 \approx 2.7\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: Two masses, $6.0\text{ kg}$ and $9.0\text{ kg}$, are connected by a light string over a frictionless, massless pulley in an Atwood machine. Calculate the magnitude of the acceleration of the system when released from rest.

A $15\text{ kg}$ block on a horizontal frictionless table is connected by a light string over a frictionless pulley to a $4.0\text{ kg}$ hanging mass. Calculate the tension in the string during motion.
questions.explanation: Acceleration: $a = \frac{m_2g}{m_1+m_2} = \frac{4.0 \times 9.8}{19} = \frac{39.2}{19} = 2.063\text{ m/s}^2$. Tension: $T = m_1a = 15 \times 2.063 \approx 30.95 \approx 31\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A lamp of mass $1.2\text{ kg}$ is hanging from the ceiling by two wires, each making an angle of $30^{\circ}$ with the horizontal ceiling. Calculate the tension in each wire.
questions.explanation: If the wires make $30^{\circ}$ with the horizontal, they make $60^{\circ}$ with the vertical. Using the vertical equilibrium: $2T\sin(60^{\circ}) = mg = 1.2 \times 9.8 = 11.76\text{ N}$. With $\sin(60^{\circ}) = 0.8660$, $2T(0.8660) = 11.76 \rightarrow T = 11.76/1.732 = 6.79\text{ N}$? Wait, careful. Actually with horizontal angle, $2T\sin(30^{\circ}) = mg$? Let's solve properly: The vertical component of each tension is $T\sin\theta$ where $\theta$ is the angle with the horizontal? Actually if the wire makes angle $30^{\circ}$ with the horizontal, then the angle with the vertical is $60^{\circ}$. The vertical component is $T\cos(60^{\circ})$ or $T\sin(30^{\circ})$? $\sin(30^{\circ}) = 0.5$, so $2T(0.5) = mg = 11.76 \rightarrow T = 11.76\text{ N}$. So $T \approx 12\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A person of mass $75\text{ kg}$ stands on a scale inside an elevator that is accelerating upward at $2.4\text{ m/s}^2$. Calculate the reading on the scale (the apparent weight) in Newtons.
questions.explanation: When accelerating upward, the normal force (scale reading) is $F_N = m(g + a) = 75(9.8 + 2.4) = 75 \times 12.2 = 915 \approx 920\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A cooling fan has blades with a radius of $0.20\text{ m}$ and rotates at $1200\text{ rpm}$ (revolutions per minute). Calculate the tangential speed of a point on the outer edge of a blade.
questions.explanation: Angular velocity: $\omega = 1200 \times \frac{2\pi}{60} = 1200 \times 0.10472 = 125.66\text{ rad/s}$. Tangential speed: $v = r\omega = 0.20 \times 125.66 \approx 25.13 \approx 25\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: An object moves in a circular path of radius $1.5\text{ m}$ with a constant period of $0.45\text{ s}$. Calculate the centripetal acceleration of the object.
questions.explanation: Centripetal acceleration: $a_c = \frac{4\pi^2 r}{T^2} = \frac{4\pi^2(1.5)}{(0.45)^2} = \frac{59.2176}{0.2025} \approx 292.4 \approx 290\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A $0.25\text{ kg}$ ball is attached to a string of length $0.80\text{ m}$ and whirled in a vertical circle. If the tension in the string at the bottom of the circle is $22\text{ N}$, calculate the speed of the ball at that point.
questions.explanation: At the bottom: $T - mg = \frac{mv^2}{r} \rightarrow 22 - 0.25(9.8) = \frac{0.25v^2}{0.80}$. $22 - 2.45 = 19.55 = \frac{0.25v^2}{0.80} \rightarrow 0.25v^2 = 15.64 \rightarrow v^2 = 62.56 \rightarrow v = \sqrt{62.56} \approx 7.91 \approx 7.9\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A pilot of mass $60\text{ kg}$ pulls out of a dive following a circular arc of radius $450\text{ m}$ at a speed of $95\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the normal force exerted by the seat on the pilot at the bottom of the arc.

A car of mass $1200\text{ kg}$ rounds a flat, unbanked curve with a radius of $50\text{ m}$ at a constant speed of $14\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the centripetal force required to keep the car on the road.

A weight of mass $0.50\text{ kg}$ is swung in a horizontal circle by a string of length $1.4\text{ m}$. If the string can withstand a maximum tension of $40\text{ N}$, calculate the maximum constant speed at which the weight can be swung without breaking the string.
questions.explanation: For horizontal circular motion, tension provides the centripetal force: $T = \frac{mv^2}{r} \rightarrow 40 = \frac{0.50v^2}{1.4} \rightarrow 0.50v^2 = 56 \rightarrow v^2 = 112 \rightarrow v = \sqrt{112} \approx 10.58 \approx 11\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: Calculate the gravitational force of attraction between two objects, each of mass $85\text{ kg}$, when their centers are $1.2\text{ m}$ apart. Use $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11}\text{ NÂ·m}^2/\text{kg}^2$.
Calculate the acceleration due to gravity on the surface of a planet that has three times the mass of Earth and twice the radius of Earth. (Take $g_{Earth} = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$.)
questions.explanation: $g_p = G\frac{3M_E}{(2R_E)^2} = \frac{3}{4} \times G\frac{M_E}{R_E^2} = 0.75 \times 9.8 = 7.35 \approx 7.4\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A $25\text{ kg}$ crate is pushed a distance of $8.0\text{ m}$ across a level floor at constant speed. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between the crate and the floor is $\mu_k = 0.35$, calculate the work done by the friction force on the crate.
questions.explanation: Friction force: $f_k = \mu_k mg = 0.35 \times 25 \times 9.8 = 0.35 \times 245 = 85.75\text{ N}$. Work done by friction: $W = -f_k d = -85.75 \times 8.0 = -686 \approx -690\text{ J}$ (negative because friction opposes the motion).

questions.question: How much work is required to accelerate a car of mass $1500\text{ kg}$ from rest to a speed of $18\text{ m/s}$? Assume all work done goes into changing the kinetic energy.
questions.explanation: $W = \Delta KE = \frac{1}{2}m(v^2 - u^2) = 0.5 \times 1500 \times (18)^2 = 750 \times 324 = 243000 = 2.43 \times 10^5 \approx 2.4 \times 10^5\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A ball of mass $0.45\text{ kg}$ traveling at $12\text{ m/s}$ hits a pile of sand and comes to a stop over a distance of $0.15\text{ m}$. Calculate the magnitude of the average resistive force exerted by the sand on the ball.
questions.explanation: Initial kinetic energy: $KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = 0.5 \times 0.45 \times (12)^2 = 0.5 \times 0.45 \times 144 = 0.5 \times 64.8 = 32.4\text{ J}$. This energy is dissipated as work done by the resistive force: $W = Fd \rightarrow F = W/d = 32.4/0.15 = 216 \approx 220\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A stone of mass $0.55\text{ kg}$ is thrown from the top of a $15\text{ m}$ high cliff with an initial speed of $10\text{ m/s}$. If it hits the ground below with a speed of $14\text{ m/s}$, calculate the amount of energy lost to air resistance during the fall.
questions.explanation: Initial total energy: $E_i = mgh + \frac{1}{2}mu^2 = 0.55(9.8)(15) + 0.5(0.55)(10)^2 = 80.85 + 27.5 = 108.35\text{ J}$. Final kinetic energy: $E_f = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = 0.5 \times 0.55 \times (14)^2 = 0.5 \times 0.55 \times 196 = 0.5 \times 107.8 = 53.9\text{ J}$. Energy lost = $108.35 - 53.9 = 54.45 \approx 54\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A $2.0\text{ kg}$ pendulum bob is released from rest at a height of $0.40\text{ m}$ above its lowest point. Neglecting friction and air resistance, calculate its speed at the bottom of the swing.
questions.explanation: Conservation of energy: $mgh = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 \rightarrow v = \sqrt{2gh} = \sqrt{2 \times 9.8 \times 0.40} = \sqrt{7.84} = 2.8\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A $1200\text{ W}$ electric motor is used to lift a $150\text{ kg}$ load vertically at a constant speed. Calculate the height the load is lifted in $6.0\text{ s}$.
questions.explanation: Power for lifting at constant speed: $P = mgv \rightarrow v = P/(mg) = 1200/(150 \times 9.8) = 1200/1470 = 0.816\text{ m/s}$. Height lifted: $h = vt = 0.816 \times 6.0 = 4.896 \approx 4.9\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A cyclist outputs a power of $220\text{ W}$ to maintain a constant speed of $8.5\text{ m/s}$ on a level road. Assuming all power is used to overcome resistive forces, calculate the total resistive force acting against the cyclist.
questions.explanation: At constant speed, power is related to force and velocity by $P = Fv$. Thus $F = P/v = 220/8.5 \approx 25.88 \approx 26\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A spring with a spring constant of $480\text{ N/m}$ is compressed by $0.15\text{ m}$ from its equilibrium length. Calculate the elastic potential energy stored in the spring.
A $3.0\text{ kg}$ mass is hung from a vertical spring, causing it to stretch by $0.12\text{ m}$. Calculate the spring constant in $\text{N/m}$.
questions.explanation: At equilibrium, $mg = kx \rightarrow k = mg/x = (3.0 \times 9.8)/0.12 = 29.4/0.12 = 245 \approx 250\text{ N/m}$.

questions.question: A $5.0\text{ kg}$ block moving East at $4.0\text{ m/s}$ collides head-on with a stationary $3.0\text{ kg}$ block. If they stick together after the collision, calculate the final velocity of the combined mass.
questions.explanation: Conservation of momentum: $m_1u_1 = (m_1+m_2)v \rightarrow 5.0 \times 4.0 = 8.0v \rightarrow v = 20/8 = 2.5\text{ m/s East}$.

questions.question: In a perfectly elastic head-on collision, a $0.80\text{ kg}$ ball moving at $6.0\text{ m/s}$ hits an identical $0.80\text{ kg}$ ball at rest. What are the final velocities of each ball?
questions.explanation: In an elastic collision between equal masses where one is initially at rest, the velocities are exchanged. Therefore the first ball comes to rest ($0\text{ m/s}$) and the second ball moves with the initial velocity of the first ($6.0\text{ m/s}$).

questions.question: A $1.2\text{ kg}$ object initially at rest explodes into two pieces. One piece of mass $0.40\text{ kg}$ flies due North at $18\text{ m/s}$. Find the velocity of the remaining piece.
questions.explanation: Conservation of momentum: $0 = m_1v_1 + m_2v_2 \rightarrow 0 = (0.40)(18) + (0.80)v_2 \rightarrow 0 = 7.2 + 0.80v_2 \rightarrow v_2 = -7.2/0.80 = -9.0\text{ m/s}$. The negative sign indicates South.

questions.question: Three resistors with resistances $15\Omega$, $25\Omega$, and $35\Omega$ are connected in series to a $24\text{ V}$ battery. Calculate the total current in the circuit.
questions.explanation: Total resistance: $R_{total} = 15 + 25 + 35 = 75\Omega$. Current: $I = V/R_{total} = 24/75 = 0.32\text{ A}$.

questions.question: A $12\text{ V}$ battery is connected in series with two resistors. If $R_1 = 40\Omega$ and the total current in the circuit is $0.20\text{ A}$, find the resistance of $R_2$.
questions.explanation: Total resistance: $R_{total} = V/I = 12/0.20 = 60\Omega$. Since $R_{total} = R_1 + R_2$, we have $R_2 = 60 - 40 = 20\Omega$.

questions.question: Calculate the equivalent resistance of a $30\Omega$, $60\Omega$, and $90\Omega$ resistor connected in parallel.
questions.explanation: Using the parallel formula: $\frac{1}{R_{eq}} = \frac{1}{30} + \frac{1}{60} + \frac{1}{90} = \frac{6}{180} + \frac{3}{180} +  rac{2}{180} = \frac{11}{180}$. Therefore $R_{eq} = 180/11 \approx 16.36 \approx 16\Omega$.

questions.question: Two resistors are connected in parallel across a $15\text{ V}$ source. If the total current supplied by the source is $5.0\text{ A}$ and one of the resistors is $6\Omega$, find the value of the second resistor.
questions.explanation: Equivalent resistance: $R_{total} = V/I = 15/5.0 = 3\Omega$. For two resistors in parallel: $\frac{1}{3} = \frac{1}{6} + \frac{1}{R_2} \rightarrow \frac{1}{R_2} = \frac{1}{3} - \frac{1}{6} = \frac{2}{6} - \frac{1}{6} = \frac{1}{6} \rightarrow R_2 = 6\Omega$.

questions.question: A $20\Omega$ resistor is connected in series with a parallel combination of two $40\Omega$ resistors. Calculate the total equivalent resistance of this circuit.
questions.explanation: The two $40\Omega$ resistors in parallel give: $R_p = \frac{40 \times 40}{40+40} = \frac{1600}{80} = 20\Omega$. Adding the series $20\Omega$ resistor: $R_{total} = 20 + 20 = 40\Omega$.

questions.question: A $36\text{ V}$ battery is connected to a circuit consisting of a $10\Omega$ resistor in series with a parallel combination of two $20\Omega$ resistors. Calculate the current through the $10\Omega$ resistor.
questions.explanation: The two $20\Omega$ resistors in parallel give: $R_p = 20/2 = 10\Omega$. Total resistance: $R_{total} = 10 + 10 = 20\Omega$. Total current (which is the same through the series $10\Omega$ resistor) is $I = V/R_{total} = 36/20 = 1.8\text{ A}$.

questions.question: A transverse wave has a wavelength of $0.45\text{ m}$ and a frequency of $150\text{ Hz}$. Calculate the speed of the wave.
questions.explanation: Using the wave equation: $v = f\lambda = 150 \times 0.45 = 67.5 \approx 68\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A string is $2.5\text{ m}$ long and has a total mass of $50\text{ g}$. If it is under a tension of $80\text{ N}$, calculate the speed of a wave on this string.
questions.explanation: Linear mass density: $\mu = m/L = 0.050/2.5 = 0.020\text{ kg/m}$. Wave speed: $v = \sqrt{T/\mu} = \sqrt{80/0.020} = \sqrt{4000} \approx 63.25 \approx 63\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A car horn emits sound at a frequency of $420\text{ Hz}$. The car approaches a stationary listener at a speed of $22\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the frequency heard by the listener. The speed of sound is $340\text{ m/s}$.
questions.explanation: For a source approaching a stationary observer: $f' = f\frac{v}{v - v_s} = 420 \times \frac{340}{340 - 22} = 420 \times \frac{340}{318} = 420 \times 1.0692 \approx 449.1 \approx 450\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: Two speakers emit sound in phase. Destructive interference is heard at a point where the path difference from the speakers is $1.2\text{ m}$. Calculate the longest possible wavelength that could produce this interference pattern.
questions.explanation: For destructive interference with in-phase sources, the condition is $\Delta x = (n + \frac{1}{2})\lambda$. The longest wavelength occurs when $n = 0$, giving $1.2 = \lambda/2 \rightarrow \lambda = 2.4\text{ m}$.

questions.question: Calculate the fundamental frequency of an open-ended organ pipe that is $0.75\text{ m}$ long. The speed of sound is $344\text{ m/s}$.
questions.explanation: For an open pipe, the fundamental wavelength is $\lambda = 2L = 1.5\text{ m}$. The fundamental frequency is $f_1 = v/\lambda = 344/1.5 \approx 229.3 \approx 230\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: Calculate the beat frequency produced by two tuning forks with frequencies of $256\text{ Hz}$ and $262\text{ Hz}$.
questions.explanation: The beat frequency is the absolute difference between the two frequencies: $f_{beat} = |262 - 256| = 6\text{ Hz}$.
